I'm assuming most of the reviews here are from early access, here's one from someone who did not play early access and has also not played any previous games in the series.  This game is very good. It's expansive, challenging but not unfair, and there's a good amount of character and party customization. It's the most RPG-y RPG I've played in a long time.   You'll travel the open world, come across riddles, puzzles, enemies and dungeons - some of which will be too high level for you. There is no level scaling and the world is crafted in a way that you're going to want to backtrack often to try and kill that boss you found who one shot you 10 hours earlier. And that's awesome. You're going to be battling your way through dungeons, barely surviving by the skin of your teeth and have to make runs back to town (actual runs, no instant click travel here) to restock on supplies so that you can continue. And that's awesome.  It's not going to be for everyone but this is a really solid, lengthy and replayable RPG with lots of substance that's built on its RPG systems and its gameplay rather than a story or dialogue choices or any of the usual modern stuff.   The only con is performance. Performance is poor in some places, and loading times especially are poor. This is exacerbated by the fact that the game freezes in the background, meaning you have to sit through the 30 second-1 minute load screens. This can get very annoying because you will often be making trips back and forth to town and there's a loading screen each time. The game also doesn't exactly look amazing and the dialogue and story are generic and half-♥♥♥♥♥. But from what I understand this is a game made by a small team mostly as a proof of concept to get this series back up and running, and it did what it set out to achieve and then some.

Arguably the most engaging CRPG in the modern era. Lots of customization, solid level of challenge, story has expanded significantly since Early Access ended.  If you want to play a 90s PC first-person 4-person party RPG with a modern polish that's actually good, here it is.

Here is a quick review for you from a M&M veteran.  Pros: -Nice story. -Nice graphics although not too good but who gives a toss about graphics anyways. -Feels like Might and Magic. -Is indeed fun. -Has a nice hotkey bar that you can place your spells on so you don't need to open your spellbook 24/7. Makes things easier in my opinion. -They finally upped the magic damage so you can sometimes 1 shot entire crowds when you crit with your spells. -Decent sound effects. -The undead look super cool. -All wizard party is a wonder to behold. With crits added, your magic attacks can do a lot of damage and the game becomes even more enjoyable and easier. It is so good that I ACCIDENTALLY KILLED EREBOS INSTEAD OF USING THE SHARDS TO SUMMON THE LIGHT FROM THE VESSEL. ♥♥♥♥ER JUST DIED BECAUSE MY CHAIN LIGHTNING HIT FOR 2 K DAMAGE AND CREDITS JUST STARTED ROLLING. - Nice dungeon design. Although since it's tile based, it's mostly visuals, not too much variety, very few secrets, traps etc. compared to the other games. It could have been a gray labyrinth and from 'gameplay' point of view, the dungeons would have basically been the same. But still they mostly look nice in my opinion. - I like Ashan better than Enroth. Has a more interesting lore in my opinion. - Crag Hack is back my dudes.  Cons. Oh boy. - Not even half of the content of mm6 mm7 or mm8. Probably inferior even to mm9. This bothered me the most. You cannot even do the promotion quests of other classes for example. Oh and there is only one promotion for each class instead of the usual two. - 4 races. 3 classes for each and class design isnt very intricate. - Obligatory tile based movement and buffs. Didnt bother me that much but still, only turn based is a bit off putting. - TONS of sound effects and textures (mostly monsters) are recycled from Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, Heroes of Might and Magic 5 and some others. - Basically one map. Really. One. Map. - Since it is so small no flying whatsoever. Very limited freedom. - WHEN YOU ARE OUT OF A BLOODY CITY, IN OPEN FIELDS, THE CITIES ARE BASICALLY AT YOUR HEIGHT. IMAGINE THJORGARD, NOW MINIMIZE IT TO YOUR HEIGHT. YES. THAT IS IT. - Unless you have like at least 2 casters, the DLC is impossible to do. - Level cap is 40. Yes. The content is that limited. - Obligatory Uplay login. Did not bother me but might be a bit off putting for other players. - Nearly all status effects last forever. I am not even gonna elaborate like this happens when you get that and such because nearly all of them are broken. Even ♥♥♥♥ing sleep doesn't get dispelled when you get damaged if I am not mistaken. You need to have casters or an endless supply of scrolls to negate status effects (which trigger roughly half of the time when creatures attack) or you literally cannot progress. - Feeblemind --> Death.  Overall this isn't as good as mm6, mm7, mm8 or even mm9. But it is nonetheless enjoyable in my opinion. Perhaps a lot more enjoyable than the other games if you go full mage. Seriously, try it. You won't be disappointed. If you like Might and Magic get this. Just don't have super high expectations and you will enjoy it.

Addendum to the Might & Magic (World of )X(een) Legacy.   It's not a bad game, but it's pretty average and a bit too much on the clunky side with a lot less freedom than previous games.  This game is somehow like a watered down spin-off from the Might & Magic 3-5 World of Xeen. It uses the same base mechanics for Map layout, Movement and Combat, which was fine twenty years ago, but feels pretty clunky today. There is also a few inclusions from Might & Magic 6 like the use of Hirelings and a few categories for Spells and Skills and the use of a Skill and Promotion system.   Character creation is more streamlined, but also more boxed in, because everything each Class can learn and to what extent is laid out bare and square with progress bars and totally locked in. You can't add more Points to a Spell or Skill than the Limit of your Rank. There are four Races, each with three distinct Classes that each represents the Might, Hybrid and Magic Class of that Race. There are no limits in regards to which Race and Class you make for your Party, but since the game has no alternative Light Source other than what Magic provides you are going to have a really hard time dealing with Dungeons and underground Areas without a Dwarf (with Fire Magic) or a Class with Light or Dark Magic. If you decide to take a Shot at the Might Achievement you would be really darksided without a Dwarf in the Party, just saying. There are also no requirements for Grandmastery of Light and Dark Magic as there is no kind of Alignment or Reputation system at all.   Combat is quite clunky. You can only attack Enemies that are on the same Line as the one you are standing on and only within a limited Range, which makes Enemy movements look really silly as they slide sideways into Combat and the only Tactic that you can really apply to Combat is to make sure to stand in a Corner, Tunnel or Doorway where the Enemies can't attack you from more than one Side and there is also a limit to how many Enemies can stand on the same Square, which means they will just wait and queue up for the Slaughter. You can only Escape as long as you don't have direct Enemy Contact, but once an Enemy stands next to you you can't move at all.   I can understand why there is no water-walking (no flight, swimming and climbing neither), because that part have been tied into the Story and added as a Roadblock, but I don't understand why there are no Town Portals or Loyds Beacons. Alternatively, you can move around from Obelisk to Obelisk once you have unlocked them and you can add Markers to the Map to remember where they are and what they are called which is visible on the World Map, but they are all quite remote. There is a Spirit Beacon referred to in the description of Primordial Magic as a Spirit Gate, but you can only have ONE one-way ticket for the whole Party despite having several Characters with the same Spell. I really hate all this pointless walking, which it becomes once you have explored it all, because there are never any interruptions or encounters on the Path. The Area Map which is the only Map that shows all the paths can't be zoomed in or out and since there are a lot of Deadends you'll be wasting a lot of time moving from Place to Place, especially when you need to buy a Rank or Spells. There is no free movement at all, but a lot of Maze like Tunnels across the Landscape, through Forests and rocky Terrain. Once you acquire the ability to walk on water you realize that there is remarkably little water that you can actually walk on.   The only really nice thing the Game offers is that you can add your own Markers to the Map, which is visible on the World Map and Area Map and helps a lot to find Trainers again and to keep track of Obelisk and remember where you've been and so on, but unfortunately the Markers you add to a disconnected Area or City is only visible within that Place.   There is also no kind of permanent Item Enchantment in the game. You can't make your own Items or Enchant them with Magical Properties. No point in lugging around anything else than Magic Items, that you intend to use.   Each character has an action bar with ten Slots, but only one. There is no switching between them or making more, which is really too limited.   There is quite a lot of Puzzles and Riddles in the game, which is a bit of a testamony to the old games, but the ones that require you to move around a lot and step on plates in different order or keep track of teleportation Paths are really quite boring and tedious and the clunky Interface is not helpful at all in this regard.   There are a few funny references to Army of Darkness and other Race specific comments to nature and actions, but unfortunately they are just barely chuckleworthy. Your Characters really bark a lot in Combat.   The Story, Sound and Dialogue is pretty decent, but the Graphics are really low-res and it doesn't really support any Resolution at all. The game looks exactly the same in 1280x800 as it does in 1920x1200. It really looks at least ten years older than it is, but due to a tremendous lacks of optimization in the Unity Engine, which is powering the Game, it's actually pretty taxing on your GPU for no reason at all. The game looks nice from a Distance with Shadows and different Light Effects, but it's really blurry up close.   I bought the game on Steam, but I also needed to install Ubisofts UPlay and create an Account in order to play the Game, but UPlay is really half-baked. It tracks my Achievements and seriously slow down loading on Area transistions, but it neither record nor unlock Actions and Rewards and thus I can't unlock any new 'free' Areas. I can't unlock any of the Game Content with Upoints.   The DLC The Falcon & The Unicorn is really short. It's like an End Chapter, which isn't available until you've finished the main Game, and it's actually quite hard. It begins with a Blast of the most cumbersome tediousness of Puzzle solving as the worst parts of the game with a massive moving around. Once you get the hang of it it's quite simple, but incredible boring, because there is really no challenge at all. Until you get it right, until you understand the mechanics it's a massive waste of time.

I really enjoyed this game, it reminded me so much of the original Might & Magic. Back before the graphics were any good and 3D rendering wasn't even a reality for desktop games. The game play is a perfect balance of old and new. Turn based takes me back, and also enhances the strategic part of this type of gaming. There are certainly some difficult sections in this game, where you can encounter monsters that are outright impossible to kill at the level you are in the game, so be careful. Monsters do not re-spawn, so it is not the kind of game where you can 'farm' for gold and/or items. You have to be careful with your resources to make sure you don't miss any opportunities to upgrade when needed to progress. Overall, I would give this game a 9/10.

In the end I really, really wanted this game to be amazing as I loved the story of Heroes VI and am a fan of this style of RPG however the game fell flat and I was simply left wanting more. I was concerned this wouldn't be a recommendation after participating in the Early Release, which was incredibly disappointing. However, I was pleasantly surprised when the final release came out that a large number of the issues I had with the game had been addressed. Overall, M&MX does a good job of capturing the old school vibe of earlier entries in the system, while taking advantage of some of their later design improvements first seen in their Heroes series of games.   That said, the game misses the mark in several ways. First, the graphic performance is very disappointing. It looks like a game optimized for 5+ years ago. The creation and skill system does a poor job of helping new players understand pros and cons of the abilities and how they impact gameplay. The amount of running through previously cleared areas is frustrating. The limited voice acting is grating and repetitive.  Despite those disappointments, this does scratch the itch for a classic, party-based, first person roleplaying experience. The exploration, discovery, hidden bits, and character classes do feel like previous entries in the system. For a truly authentic experience, and to help off-set the disappointing graphics, I strongly recommend selecting the 'classic pixelated' display found in the gameplay settings menu.   Other pros - once you're familiar with the game, the classes are diverse and offer a lot of variety in how you want to build your party. Combat is tactical enough to be satisfying without slowing the game down too much. Boss fights are brutal but winnable with careful play. The cool epic items that level up with your character are awesome. It's casual enough to be approachable by a wide audience. It's a fairly good value for its pricepoint. It has a strong nostalgia element.   I think people familiar with other games in the series will be most likely to enjoy this version, but it shouldn't stop new players from giving it a shot!

Namely, The size/scale of the game. Don't expect a huge MM6-8 style world with hundreds of side quests - The world is much smaller and the plot is quite simple. Despite that, The loading times might annoy you and it's still a bit buggy. The skill system works a bit differently as well. But other than that..  It has the spirit and feel of an MM game. I'd say it's well worth the price and Limbic should be commended for capturing NWC's spirit in this game as well. Hopefully, Next time, Ubisoft will consider a more large-scale MM game.  And even if you aren't an MM fan.. This is a pretty nice RPG in today's standards, Giving well over 40-50 hours of entertaining gameplay.

No. I'm sorry guys this isn't M&M. Not even M&M III-V, certainly not M&M VI, there is simply too much missing. This version is missing way too much. No real time movement mode. No smooth movement mode (grid movement only). No running from battles. No tactical movement during battles. No rogue or rogue-like skills. The list goes on and on.   It just feels small and too limited. Nope. Play M&M VII instead.

If you can get past the roughness of the visuals (texture resolutions seem to be aimed for sub 1080p monitors, gui doesn't scale so you have massive texts and buttons on big monitors, some cheap particle spell effects) you can find one enjoyable Dungeon Master -like game. Nice locations, interesting foes, pretty decent combat and character mechanics.  One thing they seriously need to adjust / change is how poison works. There are way too many dungeons with poison attack enemies and getting poisoned without potions means death because resting doesn't really heal you from it and you don't have cure spells in the beginning. Antidote potions were easy to come by in the first dungeon as the enemies occasionally dropped them, but in later dungeon you have ranged poison enemies (that also cause poison with melee) and no source of anything to cure it with. A bit frustrating.  edit: Apparently you can get cure poison spell with novice level earth magic, but point still stands that poison is really annoying and way too frequent effect in the beginning.  I do recommend this game though! Slow first hour, but gets really nice afterwards.

Terrific return to the series past, this installment is a return to form for this series after the disappointing M&M 9. Not quite up to the (rose tinted) M&M 6, this release is more in the vein of M&M 3 or 4; the old school charm is a welcome change of pace from “modern” RPG’s, and a reminder of how solid these games used to be. The only thing that could use further tweaking is the difficulty… Adventurer mode is too easy, while Warrior mode can be too unforgiving, especially in the early game. My advice is to play on Warrior mode, but read a class guide beforehand, as it is too easy to create a party and build that can’t progress in Act 2.   Legacy is a bit rough around the edges, but if you are a fan of Might & Magic, or RPG’s in general, this one is well worth your time!

But heck, this game has been known to be a low-cost production ever since it's been announced, so it makes no sense arguing over those now right?  Overall it's not bad but not amazingly good either. But at the very least, it's still the long awaited sequel to the Might and Magic series!

Having participated in the early-access program and completing the early stages of the game several times, and helping the developers out as they progress through the game's developerment, I can say I am so far pleased with the final product. While the game is completly tile based, it does make you think about every step you end up taking, as it uses a turn. If you have a buff, do you want to move this direction or this direction, either way it uses up a point in the spell's duration. The graphics are pretty, although it can be a little laggy even on high end machines it isn't anything to start ranting about. If you are a fan of the older type of RPG's like this, you can even set the game to 'retro mode' in the options and force the older feel pixels for the game. The game is filled with all sorts of journals giving insight to the world the game is set in. I personally sat down (breaks included of going to make a sandwich or something else more important at the moment) for a little over 3 hours to find the perfect type of class combination I wanted for my party. It is very important that you choose wisely. The game encourages you to explore the areas you are in and do not strictly require you to go from point A to point B. The way I see it is, take a shot at getting it. If you get the amout of hours in gameplay that you paid for it, then its worth the purchase. Try to avoid the ones that pick at the minor flaws and give it a bad rating.

This is a game in the old Wizardry style (or MIght & magic 3-5, Ultima 7, Etrian Odyssey, etc.). You make a party of four characters who start undergeared and weak, then explore the world and complete quests to level up and obtain better gear and spells. It's turn-based, and the map is a grid (where you can only face in cardinal directions), so it has the feel of an old game with modern graphics.  If that appeals to you, I'd say you'll enjoy Might & Magic X. If you aren't sure, then a cheaper (though older) place to start would be Might & Magic 3 or World of Xeen (which combines M&M 4 and 5). The playstyle is very similar. Legend of Grimrock isn't far off either, though that game has more emphasis on puzzles and survival.  The world is quite open (and unforgiving - save often, for you can wander into areas too tough for you without warning). The focus is on advancing your party and winning fights while you explore the world, so if you hate turn-based combat, stay far away from this one. On the other hand, if you like exploring dungeons and trying different party builds and skill choices to fight your way to victory, this is a solid game. It doesn't necessarily do anything new, but does a great job of paying homage to a type of game you don't see much anymore in the West.  Note that this game does use uPlay, Ubisoft's client, and keeps it running while the game runs. However, the dev has said that you only need to be online for the initial game launch, and after that you can run uPlay in offline mode without any problem.

If you're a fan of the series you will love what they brought back, and the inside jokes from past games. If you're not a fan, I suggest you look for something more modern. This is a turn based RPG. Time moves as you do. Certain classes can only use certain things. This is not like skyrim where you can have mastered every form of magic and go running around in platemale that you have grandmastered and made yourself at home with your kids watching. Even looking past superficials like the unpolished graphics and lack of voice acting (things one would assume to be better with a AAA publisher) the mechanics are overly shallow such that most people will probably burn out on the excessive content due to tedium.  Melee is very basic with only one talent tree and limited attacks. Range is pointless given the number of ambushes you face (and there's a penalty for shooting things at point blank/melee range). The magic schools don't feel sufficiently different and mostly consist of nukes plus a couple of superfluous buff spells. Yes, there are towns and quests and merchants and the occassional puzzle but all of it is very rudimentary. Itemization is terrible consisting of a few hand placed relics with the rest being randomized Diablo-style crap.  MMX Legacy should be more polished and deeper than Grimrock (and not merely a turn-based alternative). It isn't. Moreoever it is arguably worse in some aspects like level design, character progression, itemization, etc. You're better off playing the old Bard's Tale series as the graphics are only slightly worse but the gameplay is much deeper. But that was funded by Interplay, right? Well... this was ostensibly funded by Ubisoft. Apparently not. A shame. Had they given this the funding they put in other iteration of the M&M series this would have been a fantastic game. In its current condition it is mediocre at best.

Monster fighting is the battle on who has more potions. This kind of game design maybe interesting 20 years ago. But to produce such a game at 21st century and charge people 25 dollars for it is simply not acceptable. There are some interesting puzzles, but not enough to make the game attractive.  Then here comes the cheapskate strategy of reduce, recycle and reuse. Ubisoft used this strategy on heroes VI, I still bear with it. However, what is this? The monster appearance, NPCs, music and every other thing you see basically comes from dark messiah and heroesVI. Being of the same world Ashan, I guess some repetition is fine. Forcing elements of these two games into one feels like a big modded rpg from some random players community like WOG. Not to mention the texture and graphic is horrible. Some people say it doesn't work with 32bit OS, but my win8 64bit seems to have the same problem as well. In one word: they shouldn't charge 25USD just for a recycled product.  In conclusion, I am not against turn-based strategy games or rpg. But this game is nowhere on par with any decent modern day rpg. It is good for nostalgia. Playing on Warrior difficulty, there were some definitely challenging moments, but I managed to make it through despite picking sub-optimal character classes.   At the end of the day, it was a good solid dungeon crawl with an old-school feel. Recommended for someone who wants a dungeon crawl with the occasional puzzle.

You might be able to complete their dungeon without pain, and still have to keep away from them, go somewhere else leveling and getting better equipment, then come back for a hard fight. I don't like the map designs, with at times just annoying path blockers, put there for no apparent reason, and towns are too big (while it makes for a real town for a grid based game it makes it a labor to travel the streets). Overall design quality isn't really good and game is unoptimized. Running into the forest and jungle kills FPS to a stop.  Story wise you get a common story which is neither good nor bad per se. A Welcome Return To Old School RPG Gaming  For the tl;dr crowd:  Pros: * Really truly does recapture the feeling of old school Might & Magic games, particularly the World of Xeen games (which was what this was patterned after) * Tough but fair * Strategic combat  Cons: * Optimization issues * Requires UPlay (It's Ubisoft, no way around UPlay, unfortunately)  Now for the long winded review:  When I first heard about this game I was first of all shocked, as it had been so long since a core Might & Magic game had been released (I bet there is a contingent of people that prior to the release of this game though Heroes of Might & Magic was the core series, rather than the spinoff it is) that I just assumed the series was dead and buried. I was both excited and a bit scared. Excited because holy smokes a new core Might & Magic game! Scared because it was being made by a developer I didn't really know and that had, to the best of my knowledge, no prior experience making an old school RPG like this. Would they be able to recapture the Might & Magic feeling? Would they get the mechanics right? Would they try to modernize it too much?  After reading up on the team and following their blog for a bit, it became apparent that these people were a fan of the games and genuinely passionate about making an old school RPG. They also revealed that they were patterning this game after World of Xeen (M&M 4 & 5), going with turn-based and grid-based, rather than free movement and real-time, like M&M 6-9. While I enjoyed M&M 6-8 quite a bit, 9 not so much, I was also a huge fan of the World of Xeen games and was happy with this decision, so I decided to pull the trigger and get this.  I can now happily say that I chose wisely. This game has exceeded my expectations. While the game isn't exactly pushing graphical boundaries and there are some jarringly low res models and textures mixed in, the game is plenty pretty enough for my tastes and it has a certain charm to it. I suspect Ubisoft didn't exactly give Limbic a massive budget to work with, so I wasn't expecting The Witcher 2 levels of eye candy. Much more importantly, this is an honest to goodness old school Might & Magic game. The setting and story follow the Heroes of Might & Magic games timeline rather than M&M 9, but mechanically they really did a great job of recreating the World of Xeen gameplay.  There are 12 classes among 4 races to choose from (3 per race) filling the roles of fighters, casters, and various hybrids in between. The game doesn't hold your hand and you learn on the job, which may be a turn off for some gamers, but is very welcome in my book. Certain class combinations will work better than other, and it's certainly possible to build a party that's going to get stomped in the game, but there is room for a variety of different viable combination. Balanced parties (a mix of warrior and mage types) will naturally work the best, as they usually do in RPGs, but it's possible to go mage-heavy (though you will burn through a lot of mana potions) or warrior-heavy and still succeed.  The game is quite challenging, but not cheap. There are 2 difficulty settings: Adventurer and Warrior, corresponding to Normal and Hard respectively, though, compared to the average game of these days, they're more like Hard and Very Hard. This game will kick your behind and you will die. There is no sleepwalking through fights except for the most basic of weak enemies. If you try to sleepwalk on simply brute force your way (even with a warrior-heavy party) through battles you will get destroyed. You have to use your head to survive. The game constantly puts you into confrontations where you are surviving by your wits and the skin of your teeth, and that's on Adventurer difficulty. Warrior difficulty is straight up punishing, and I love it!  There is a good bit of strategy in using your various spells and abilities to protect yourself, buff your allies, debuff enemies, debilitate them, and deal damage. Plus the grid-based movement adds another layer of tactics, making for a chess-like game of maneuvering where you try to lure ranged enemies into melee without getting pelted by arrows and spells while advancing on them, or getting as many 'free' volleys of arrows on melee enemies before they close to melee, all while being mindful of the terrain to position yourself in a spot to prevent being flanked or surrounded. It's a well thought out system that forces you to use all the skills at your disposal. It can seem overwhelming when you're caught off guard and a group of enemies creeps up behind you while other enemies close in from the front and you're caught in a vice in a seemingly hopeless battle, frantically trying to keep your party members alive while trying to take out key enemies before they can demolish you. But when you survive a battle like that, it's that much more satisfying, so much better than mindlessly steamrolling through trash mobs like in so many RPGs.   In conclusion, Might & Magic is a throwback to the RPGs of the 80s and the 90s, with much of the good and the bad that comes with that. It's a wonderful nostalgia ride and Limbic did a terrific job of delivering an authentic old school RPG experience. It's thoroughly challenging and quite satisfying. If you're looking for an old-school turn-based RPG romp, look no further.

I loved it and had a great time playing it, but you may not. So, let's discuss it's progency, for a moment.  The game owes it's existence to the joyful Legend of Grimrock, which did a great job updating the games of my youth. MMX is an even more direct throwback to the original Bard's Tale in 1985. The Bard's Tale took Wizardry and added outdoor areas. Sure, they weren't that different -- they were basically dungeons with sky blue tiles as opposed to underground grey and brown tiles, but the effect worked on me.   If you have some nostalgia for the early days of RPG gaming, this will likely hit a home run. It reminds me of playing games on my Apple II, even including watching the graphics render. What I really enjoyed most was developing my characters and watching them become increasingly powerful. I wanted them well prepared for the final battle, and there are many opportunities to improve their skills and their loot.  Pros: - RPG nostalgia - Good skills and character development options - Good magic system - The individual quests and dungeon were mostly fun - Combat is well done - To me, at least, the game is almost perfectly balanced (with the stock party). Only toward the end did I begin to feel overpowered. Most of the game, the battles were close and tense, but rarely did my entire party die. - Great opportunities for exploration -- there is always something new to find - No monster respawns!! Once you clear an area, it stays clear. I like that.  Cons: - Graphics look good, but take a long time to render. At one point, the landscape renders well before the castle sitting on the landscape renders. That's just weird. - Members have your party have comments about everything going on around them. I love that. Except that they repeat the same things over and over and over again. We get it... human cities are as dangerous as the jungle. Let's move on. When characters finish a major battle, they cheer an entirely disingenuous 'Yay!' It sounds exactly like a bunch of poorly paid actors sitting around their home microphones trying to appear enthusiastic. - With some exceptions, most of the battles use pretty much the same tactics. I had the same criticism of Dragon Age. So this game is not unique, in this regard.  I've invested about 55 hours into this game. And I had a lot of fun doing it. If you have a soft spot in your heart for the RPG dungeon-crawling heyday of the 80s, I think you'll really enjoy this. I sure did.
